939A43636B0F47F09DC5CB163FA749F9.description:
Know that alkenes can be formed from alcohols by acid-catalysed elimination reactions.
Be able to outline the mechanism for the acid-catalysed dehydration of an alcohol to form an alkene by drawing the structures of the species involved and curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.
Know that alkenes produced by this method can be used to produce addition polymers without using monomers derived from crude oil.

F8BC2886DCAB41F6890D162AE3BBE361.description:
Know that alcohols are classified as primary, secondary and tertiary.
Know that primary alcohols can be oxidised to aldehydes, which can be further oxidised to carboxylic acids; that secondary alcohols can be oxidised to ketones and that tertiary alcohols are not easily oxidised.
Know that a suitable oxidising agent for these reactions is acidified potassium dichromate (VI).
Be able to write equations for these oxidation reactions, using [O] to represent the oxidising agent.
Explain how the method used to oxidise a primary alcohol determines whether an aldehyde or a carboxylic acid is obtained.
Know the use of chemical tests to distinguish between aldehydes and ketones, including Fehling’s solution and Tollens’ reagent.

E3482721D0B64E9B884F1A368586959A.description:
Know that alcohols have many scientific, medicinal and industrial uses.
Know that alcohols are produced industrially by the hydration of alkenes in the presence of an acid catalyst.
Be able to outline the mechanism for the acid-catalysed hydration of an alkene to form an alcohol by drawing the structures of the species involved and curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.
Know how ethanol is produced industrially by fermentation of glucose and the conditions for this process.
Know that ethanol produced by fermentation is separated by fractional distillation and can then be used as a biofuel.
Justify the conditions used in the production of ethanol by fermentation.
Be able to write equations to support the statement that ethanol produced by fermentation is a carbon-neutral fuel and give reasons why this statement is not valid.
Explain the meaning of the term biofuel.
Discuss the environmental and ethical issues linked to decision making regarding the use of biofuels.

B709C2C369E148D69A50A515B14B22B9.description:
Know that addition polymers are formed from alkenes and substituted alkenes.
(The details of addition polymers will be left till the U6th year.)

D3D5B3440B44401E8524243A368D6924.description:
Understand how alkenes undergo electrophilic addition reactions with Br2, HBr and H2SO4
Be able to outline the mechanism for these electrophilic addition reactions by drawing the structures of the species involved and curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs (the formation of a covalent bond is shown by a curly arrow that starts from a lone pair of electrons or from another covalent bond; the breaking of a covalent bond is shown by a curly arrow starting from the bond).
Be able to explain the formation of major and minor products in addition reactions of unsymmetrical alkenes by reference to the relative stabilities of primary, secondary and tertiary carbocation intermediates.
Know the use of bromine water to test for unsaturation.

10FE6B7638AC46EC96DB4738C13C5815.description:
Know that alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons.
Know that the bonding in alkenes involves a double covalent bond, a centre of high electron density, which is attacked by electrophiles.

A4622740FD0C4CCA86B1965DF4D65E5E.description:
Understand that the use of some halogenoalkanes has been restricted due to the effect of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) on the atmosphere.
Know that ozone, formed naturally in the upper atmosphere, is beneficial because it absorbs ultraviolet radiation.
Understand how chlorine atoms are formed in the upper atmosphere when UV radiation causes C–Cl bonds in CFCs to break.
Know that chlorine atoms catalyse the decomposition of ozone and contribute to the hole in the ozone layer.
Be able to use equations, such as the following, to explain how chlorine atoms catalyse ozone decomposition:
Cl∙ + O3  →  ClO∙ + O2  and  ClO∙ + O3  →  2O2 +  Cl∙
Appreciate that results of research by different groups in the scientific community provided evidence for legislation to ban the use of CFCs as solvents and refrigerants.  Chemists have now developed alternative chlorine-free compounds.

46FF95B6CEFB4530873E353729730892.description:
Understand that elimination and substitution occur concurrently when a halogenoalkane reacts with a strong base like potassium hydroxide.
Explain the role of the reagent as both a nucleophile and a base.
Be able to outline the mechanism for the elimination reaction, using curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.

ED08799B046B41B7865807B53481853E.description:
Know that halogenoalkanes are more reactive than alkanes because they contain polar bonds.
Understand that halogenoalkanes undergo nucleophilic substitution reactions with the nucleophiles OH–, CN– and NH3.
Be able to outline the mechanism for these nucleophilic substitution reactions by drawing the structures of the species involved and curly arrows to represent the movement of electron pairs.
The formation of a covalent bond is shown by a curly arrow that starts from a lone pair of electrons or from another covalent bond.
The breaking of a covalent bond is shown by a curly arrow starting from the bond.
Explain why the carbon–halogen bond enthalpy influences the rate of the substitution reaction.

2F58A908AE0347B2B2F5E634A2614FA4.description:
Know the reaction of methane with chlorine.
Be able to explain this reaction as a free-radical substitution mechanism involving initiation, propagation and termination steps.
Understand that the unpaired electron in a radical is represented by a dot and that the use of curly arrows is not required for this mechanism.
Be able to write balanced equations for the steps in a free-radical mechanism.

EDDDCF76A87E45B49D13F8409AC86653.description:
Know that alkanes are used as fuels.
Know that combustion of alkanes and other organic compound can be complete or incomplete.
Know that the internal combustion engine produces a number of pollutants, including NOx, CO, carbon and unburned hydrocarbons, and that these pollutants can be removed using catalytic converters.
Know that combustion of hydrocarbons containing sulfur leads to sulfur dioxide that causes air pollution.
Explain why sulfur dioxide can be removed from flue gases using calcium oxide or calcium carbonate.

09CE218661354D96B6E76F6D7EA168AE.description:
Know that cracking involves breaking C–C bonds in alkanes.
Know that thermal cracking takes place at high temperatures and high pressures and produces a high percentage of alkenes.
Know that catalytic cracking takes place at a slight pressure, high temperature and in the presence of a zeolite catalyst and is used mainly to produce motor fuels and aromatic hydrocarbons.
(Neither mechanism for cracking is required.)
Be able to explain the economic reasons for cracking alkanes.

3406774EF79E45DAB14F9AE8D0D7351C.description:
Know that alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons.
Know that petroleum (crude oil) is a mixture consisting mainly of alkane hydrocarbons that can be separated by fractional distillation.

C7F54DDFEB9D4615906D0D3F2A46F7AF.description:
Know that optical isomerism is a form of stereoisomerism which occurs as a result of chirality in molecules, limited to molecules with a single chiral centre.
Know that an asymmetric carbon atom is chiral and gives rise to optical isomers (enantiomers) which exist as non-superimposable mirror images.
Know that enantiomers differ in their effect on plane polarised light.
Be able to draw both structural and displayed formulae of enantiomers.

For U6th later:
Know that a mixture of equal amounts of enantiomers is called a racemic mixture (racemate) and is optically inactive.
Understand how racemic mixtures are formed and why they are optically inactive.

E390DDB7D4094FA29CBB62035F5B3B4E.description:
Define the term structural isomer.
Be able to draw the structures of chain, position and functional group isomers.
Define the term stereoisomer.
Know that E-Z isomerism is a form of stereoisomerism which occurs as a result of restricted bond rotation about the planar C=C double bond.
Be able to draw the structural formulae of E and Z isomers.
Understand and be able to apply the Cahn-Ingold-Prelog (CIP) priority rules to E and Z isomers.

E369573C9BA24BE7BB8EBE5D83CD0F03.description:
Know that organic compounds can be represented by the following:
empirical formula; molecular formula; general formula; structural formula; displayed formula; skeletal formula. Be able to draw structural, displayed and skeletal formulae for given organic compounds.
Know the IUPAC rules for nomenclature.
Be able to apply IUPAC rules for nomenclature to name organic compounds, limited to chains and rings with up to six carbon atoms each.
Be able to apply IUPAC rules for nomenclature to draw the structure of an organic compound from the IUPAC name, limited to chains and rings with up to six carbon atoms each.
Understand the characteristics of a homologous series, a series of compounds containing the same functional group.

98E63A64349E4175B4F3CEC829B0E1D9.description:
Know the reaction of chlorine with water to form chloride ions and chlorate (I) ions.
Know the reaction of chlorine with water to form chloride ions and oxygen (UV light present).
Know the reaction of chlorine with cold, dilute NaOH and uses of the solution formed.
Know the use of chlorine in water treatment.
Appreciate that society assesses the advantages and disadvantages when deciding if chemicals should be added to water supplies.
Appreciate that the benefits to health of water treatment by chloride outweigh its toxic effects.

76E71C1BE7654BCEA49CD2C4C2DF7EEB.description:
Know the trends in electronegativity and boiling point of the halogens.
Be able to explain these trends using understanding of atomic structure and bonding.
Know the trend in oxidising ability of the halogen elements down the group, including displacement reactions of halide ions in aqueous solution.
Be able to explain the trend in oxidising ability of the elements.
Know the trend in reducing ability of the halide ions, including the reactions of solid sodium halides with concentrated sulfuric acid.
Be able to explain the trend in reducing ability of the halide ions.
Know the use of acidified silver nitrate solution to identify and distinguish between halide ions.
Know the trend in solubility of the silver halides in ammonia solution.
Be able to explain why silver nitrate solution is used to identify halide ions, why it must be acidified and why ammonia solution is added.

26993CDBFDF943949A6821BD64F25BB2.description:
Know that oxidation is the process of electron loss.
Define an oxidising agent as an electron acceptor.
Know that reduction is the process of electron gain.
Define a reducing agent as an electron donor.
Know the rules for assigning oxidation numbers.
Be able to work out the oxidation state of an element in a compound or ion from the formula.
Be able to construct half-equations identifying the oxidation and reduction processes in redox reactions
Be able to combine half equations to give an overall redox equation.

A6ED6314CC53422D8AD3EDC968CC0C41.description:
Know that the equilibrium constant, Kp, is deduced from the equation for a reversible reaction occurring in the gas phase, using the partial pressures of components, e.g., pX.
Be able to derive partial pressures from mole fractions and the total pressure.
Be able to construct an expression for Kp for a homogeneous system in equilibrium at constant temperature.
Be able to perform calculations involving Kp.
Be able to predict the qualitative effects of changes in temperature on the value of Kp.
Understand that, whilst a catalyst can affect the rate of attainment of an equilibrium, it does not affect the value of the equilibrium constant.

9E35D2E6952846A7AE9B25109CCB03A5.description:
Know that the equilibrium constant, Kc, is deduced from the equation for a reversible reaction, using the concentrations of components, e.g., [X].
Be able to construct an expression for Kc for a homogeneous system in equilibrium.
Be able to calculate a value for Kc from the equilibrium concentrations for a homogeneous system at constant temperature.
Be able to perform calculations involving Kc.
Know that the value of Kc is not affected by changes in concentration or the addition of a catalyst.
Be able to predict the qualitative effects of changes in temperature on the value of Kc.

1566399C8C5849F6A8F0308ECE8283B6.description:
Appreciate that many chemical reactions are reversible. 
Understand that in a reversible reaction at equilibrium the forward and reverse reactions proceed at equal rates and the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.
Understand and use le Chatelier’s principle to predict the qualitative effects of changes in temperature, pressure and concentration on the position of equilibrium in homogeneous reactions.
Know that a catalyst does not alter the position of equilibrium.
Explain why a compromise temperature and pressure may be used in an industrial process involving a reversible reaction.

005FA3ECDE4F4B16BD8560BAC1B595A7.description:
Know that the rate equation is an experimentally determined relationship.
Be able to do the following:
use concentration–time graphs to deduce the rate of a reaction; use initial concentration–time data to deduce the initial rate of a reaction; use rate–concentration data or graphs to deduce the order with respect to a reactant (0, 1, or 2); Derive the rate equation for a reaction from the orders with respect to each of the reactants.
Know that the orders with respect to reactants can provide information about the mechanism of a reaction.
Be able to use orders with respect to reactants to provide information about the rate determining / limiting step of a reaction.

B44C82F10C174FF793A32D7F4139BEBB.description:
Know that the rate of a chemical reaction is related to the concentrations  of reactants by a rate equation of the form:
Rate = k [A]m [B]n (with orders restricted to the values 0, 1 and 2). Be able to define the terms order of reaction and rate constant.
Be able to perform calculations using the rate equation.
Know that the rate constant, k, varies with temperature according to the Arrhenius equation:
k=A e-EaRT. Explain the qualitative effects of changes in temperature on k.
Be able to perform calculations using the Arrhenius equation.
Understand that the Arrhenius equation can be rearranged into logarithmic form k = –Ea/RT + ln A.
Know how to use this rearranged equation with experimental data to plot a straight line graph with slope –Ea/R.

27B485A7048249B8A4D6F594A39328F0.description:
Know that a catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being changed in chemical composition or amount.
Understand that catalysts work by providing an alternative route of lower activation energy.
Be able to use the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution to explain how a catalyst increases the rate of a reaction involving a gas.

DA413DA49AAF45C789D65ED8C2BAC50A.description:
Describe the qualitative effects of changes in concentration and gas pressure on collision frequency.
Explain how changes in concentration and gas pressure influence the rate of a reaction.

4A0DD54037AB430C956DA07C0F7C7A6A.description:
Understand the meaning of the term rate of reaction.
Describe the qualitative effect of temperature changes on the rate of reaction.
Be able to use the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution to explain why a small temperature increase can lead to a large increase in rate.

FEF3CDB15DDA4DE3B8A4C728DDB6B598.description:
Know the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution of molecular energies in gases.
Be able to draw and interpret distribution curves for different temperatures.

479C95E2D5FB4B81AA48764B53F0EDE1.description:
Understand that reactions can only occur when collisions take place between particles having sufficient energy.
Define the term activation energy.
Explain why most collisions do not lead to a reaction.

97327A582EC947DBBED8F3ED3E2A0897.description:
Be able to define each of the following terms in a Born-Haber cycle:
enthalpy of formation; ionisation energy; enthalpy of atomisation; bond enthalpy; electron affinity; lattice enthalpy (both dissociation and formation). Be able to construct Born-Haber cycles to calculate lattice enthalpy or one of the other quantities.
Compare lattice enthalpies from Born-Haber cycles with those from calculations based on a perfect ionic model to provide evidence for covalent character in ionic compounds.
Define the term enthalpy of hydration.
Be able to perform calculations involving lattice enthalpy, enthalpies of hydration and enthalpy of solution.

C5444FCEA90C406586912129E9E72166.description:
Define the term mean bond enthalpy.
Be able to use mean bond enthalpies to calculate an approximate value of ΔH for reactions in the gaseous phase.
Explain why values from mean bond enthalpy calculations differ from those determined using Hess’s law.

255AA5AA93324C43A50ED65C45DE25DC.description:
Know Hess’s law.
Be able to apply Hess’s law to perform calculations, including enthalpy changes for reactions using enthalpies of formation or combustion.

EFA974880A5F4CAFA77EC5A33C61FE28.description:
Know the equation involving heat change, q, in a reaction:  q = mc ΔT
Be able to use the equation in calculations, including finding the molar enthalpy change for a reaction.

ABC1CB646DBA4D1EA0FF6E42685E9F8F.description:
Know that reactions can be exothermic or endothermic.
Define enthalpy change (ΔH) as the heat energy change measured under constant pressure.
Know that standard enthalpy changes refer to standard conditions of 100kPa pressure and a stated temperature, e.g., 298K.
Define the standard enthalpy of combustion (ΔcHϴ)
Define the standard enthalpy of formation (ΔfHϴ).

2512FB06E84C4571B37AD39DA1DD8122.description: Explain the melting points of elements in Period 3 (Na – Ar) in terms of their bonding and structure.

515CA753356B4F67BC26B12492FD4175.description:
Know the three types of intermolecular forces:
permanent dipole – dipole forces; induced dipole – dipole (van der Waals, dispersion, London) forces; hydrogen bonding. Be able to explain the existence of these forces between molecules.
Explain how melting and boiling points of molecular substances are influenced by the strength of these intermolecular forces.
Know the importance of hydrogen bonding in the low density of ice and the anomalous boiling points of compounds.

D4ECA2CC575144A9813903866CFEA056.description:
Define the term electronegativity.
Understand that the electron distribution in a covalent bond between elements with different electronegativities will be unsymmetrical, producing a polar covalent bond, which can result in the molecule having a permanent dipole.
Be able to use partial charges to show that a bond is polar.
Be able to explain why some molecules with polar bonds do not possess a permanent dipole.

A1E9C52C742A48A89C8558104E433E95.description: Understand VSEPR theory in order to explain the shapes of, and bond angles in, simple molecules and ions with up to six electron pairs (including lone pairs) surrounding the central atom.

47EF66306DB8405388864186EF6F715E.description:
Describe the four types of crystal structure and know the following examples of each type:
ionic – sodium chloride; metallic – magnesium; macromolecular (giant covalent) – diamond and graphite; molecular – ice and iodine.
Be able to draw diagrams to represent these structures involving specified numbers of particles.
Be able to relate the melting point and conductivity of materials to the type of structure and the bonding present.
Be able to explain the energy changes associated with change of state.

F6D5B7FCD5194950996177FB861F5489.description: Understand that metallic bonding involves attraction between delocalised electrons and positive ions arranged in a lattice.

019F5C546073447883A22D2A1C8F4FC8.description:
Know that a single covalent bond contains a shared pair of electrons and that multiple bonds contain multiple pairs of electrons.
Know that a co-ordinate (dative covalent) bond contains a pair of shared electrons with both electrons supplied by one atom.
Be able to draw diagrams representing covalent bonds using lines and a co-ordinate bond using an arrow.

EF3B6D474F3A46A99A8330216C57D225.description:
Understand that ionic bonding involves electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions in a lattice.
Know the formulae for compound ions, e.g., ammonium, hydroxide, carbonate, nitrate and sulfate.

7F51C24DCDCE4F649B334EDE1321F555.description: Be able to write balanced full and ionic equations for reactions studied. Be able to deduce and balance equations for unfamiliar reactions when reactants and products are specified. Define the term percentage atom economy. Appreciate that there are economic, ethical and environmental advantages for society and for industry of developing chemical processes with a high atom economy. Be able to use balanced equations to calculate: masses, volumes of gases, percentage yields, percentage atom economies and concentrations and volumes for reactions in solution.

678A772E73DB48988AB7CC0BF966CA50.description:
Define the terms empirical formula and molecular formula.
Understand the relationship between empirical and molecular formulae.
Be able to calculate an empirical formula from data giving composition by mass or percentage mass.
Be able to calculate a molecular formula from the empirical formula and the relative molecular mass.

13FFF14CD4BA4BD18B64F7FEA25084E0.description:
Know the Ideal Gas Equation PV = nRT with the variables in SI units.
Be able to use the equation in calculations.

828F6D06705F428488C00CA84DE0339A.description:
Understand the Avogadro constant as the number of particles in a mole, applied to electrons, atoms, molecules, ions, formulae and equations.
Be able to carry out calculations involving the Avogadro constant.
Be able to carry out calculations using mass of substance, Mr and amount in moles.
Understand the concentration of a substance in solution in mol dm-3
Be able to carry out calculations using concentration, volume and amount of a substance in solution.

EBFB6EE260124E24B996BF45D3BE486B.description:
Know that relative atomic and molecular / formula masses are measured relative to 12C. (The term formula mass will be used for ionic compounds.)
Define the term relative atomic mass (Ar)
Define the term relative molecular mass (Mr)

CCDB4488FDA54BDAAFDB270015A64ABB.description:
Be able to classify an element as s, p, d or f block according to is position in the Periodic Table, which is determined by its proton number.
Explain the trends in atomic radius and first ionisation energy for elements in Period 3 (Na – Ar).

3B57B6412E424CBC886D903928B0B863.description:
Understand electron configurations of atoms and ions up to Z=36 in terms of shells, subshells s, p and d, and orbitals.
Define first ionisation energy.
Be able to write equations for first and successive ionisation energies.
Explain how first and successive ionisation energies in Period 3 (Na – Ar) and in Group 2 (Be – Ba) give evidence for electron configuration in sub-shells and shells.

1DC138D18B2D45BA805F065E5DD89BD9.description:
Know that mass spectrometry can be used to determine the molecular formula of a compound.
Be able to use precise atomic masses and the precise molecular mass to determine the molecular formula of a compound.

0CAEC40100EF40F3A1CCE6FA2888E85A.description:
Define the terms Mass Number (A) and Atomic Number (Z).
Determine the number of fundamental particles in atoms and ions using mass number, atomic number and charge.
Explain the existence of isotopes.
Describe the principles of a simple time of flight (ToF) mass spectrometer, limited to ionisation, acceleration to constant kinetic energy, ion drift, ion detection and data analysis.
Know that the mass spectrometer gives accurate information about relative isotopic mass and relative abundances of isotopes.
Know that mass spectrometry can be used to identify elements.
Be able to interpret simple mass spectra of elements and to calculate relative atomic mass from isotopic abundances (limited to mononuclear ions).
Know that mass spectrometry can be used to determine relative molecular mass.

937CBCD248DB4CBA8F74D72543B6A993.description:
Appreciate that knowledge and understanding of science has evolved over time.
Know the relative masses and charges of protons, neutrons and electrons.
Understand that an atom consists of a central nucleus containing protons and neutrons surrounded by electrons.
